dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2016, Berkshire Hathaway's biggest holding was Kraft Heinz—over 18% of their portfolio.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty sixteen, Berkshire Hathaway's biggest holding was Kraft Heinz-over eighteen percent of their portfolio.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kraft Heinz Position: 325.6 M shares Market Value: $25.3B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 18.7%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they had, uh, 326 million shares in that one company alone. That's a huge bet on packaged food.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they had, uh, three hundred twenty six million shares in that one company alone. That's a huge bet on packaged food.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kraft Heinz Position: 325.6 M shares Market Value: $25.3B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 18.7%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Wells Fargo was number two—481 million shares. I mean, that's a massive position even for Buffett.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Wells Fargo was number twominus four hundred eighty one million shares. I mean, that's a massive position even for Buffett.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wells Fargo Position: 479.7 M shares Market Value: $24 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 17.7%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, though it's interesting how concentrated the top few holdings are. Coca-Cola, IBM… they really lean into their strongest convictions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, though it's interesting how concentrated the top few holdings are. Coca-Cola, I B M... they really lean into their strongest convictions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But you know, it's not just about the size—it's the patience. Some of these they've held for decades.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But you know, it's not just about the size-it's the patience. Some of these they've held for decades.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh for sure. Like Coca-Cola? That's been in there forever. But then you see newer ones like Phillips 66 pop up in more recent filings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh for sure. Like Coca-Cola? That's been in there forever. But then you see newer ones like Phillips sixty six pop up in more recent filings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm. And even though Wal-Mart was only 2.9% of the portfolio at the time, it's still a multi-billion dollar stake.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm. And even though Wal-Mart was only two point nine percent of the portfolio at the time, it's still a multi-billion dollar stake.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wal-Mart Position: 56.2 M shares Market Value: $3.8 B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 2.8%

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild when you think about it—even their "smaller" positions are bigger than most funds' entire portfolios.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild when you think about it-even their smaller positions are bigger than most funds' entire portfolios.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And you notice how heavy they are on consumer staples and financials? Kraft, Coke, AmEx…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And you notice how heavy they are on consumer staples and financials? Kraft, Coke, AmEx...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Classic Buffett. Bet on brands and moats. Though IBM didn't exactly play out as hoped, did it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Classic Buffett. Bet on brands and moats. Though I B M didn't exactly play out as hoped, did it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: No, it didn't. But that's why diversification matters, even for them. They've got DaVita, US Bancorp…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it didn't. But that's why diversification matters, even for them. They've got DaVita, U S Bancorp...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True. And you know, seeing all this just reminds me—it's not stock picking, it's business owning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True. And you know, seeing all this just reminds me-it's not stock picking, it's business owning.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Hundred percent. Long-term mindset beats short-term noise every time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hundred percent. Long-term mindset beats short-term noise every time.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2016, Berkshire Hathaway's biggest holding was Kraft Heinz—over 18% of their portfolio.
HostB: Yeah, and they had, uh, 326 million shares in that one company alone. That’s a huge bet on packaged food.
HostA: And Wells Fargo was number two—481 million shares. I mean, that’s a massive position even for Buffett.
HostB: Right, though it’s interesting how concentrated the top few holdings are. Coca-Cola, IBM… they really lean into their strongest convictions.
HostA: Exactly. But you know, it’s not just about the size—it’s the patience. Some of these they’ve held for decades.
HostB: Oh for sure. Like Coca-Cola? That’s been in there forever. But then you see newer ones like Phillips 66 pop up in more recent filings.
HostA: Mhm. And even though Wal-Mart was only 2.9% of the portfolio at the time, it’s still a multi-billion dollar stake.
HostB: It’s wild when you think about it—even their "smaller" positions are bigger than most funds’ entire portfolios.
HostA: Absolutely. And you notice how heavy they are on consumer staples and financials? Kraft, Coke, AmEx…
HostB: Classic Buffett. Bet on brands and moats. Though IBM didn’t exactly play out as hoped, did it?
HostA: No, it didn’t. But that’s why diversification matters, even for them. They’ve got DaVita, US Bancorp…
HostB: True. And you know, seeing all this just reminds me—it’s not stock picking, it’s business owning.
HostA: Hundred percent. Long-term mindset beats short-term noise every time.
HostB: Couldn’t agree more.
